items.title: No Man's Sky Fugitive Run
items.content_html:
Finished a cool little permadeath fugitive run in No Man’s Sky last night. Just get through the center of Euclid, with some rpg restrictions:

  • No starter ship, normal space station, or Anomaly.
  • No talking to aliens/vendors etc except in pirate systems or if they land near me while I’m on foot
  • Need to use the ship builder to create an unregistered ship before leaving first system.
  • Pirate systems are ok
  • Can build base in caves of pirate systems

Took me 6 hours walking to find my first ship, a fighter, but then they started to come together quicker. Got up to 7 glyphs in the starter system and the first pirate system, so made a freighter, then found a portal to get close to the center.
items.content_text: Finished a cool little permadeath fugitive run in No Man's Sky last night. Just get through the center of Euclid, with some rpg restrictions: * No starter ship, normal space station, or Anomaly. * No talking to aliens/vendors etc except in pirate systems or if they land near me while I'm on foot * Need to use the ship builder to create an unregistered ship before leaving first system. * Pirate systems are ok * Can build base in caves of pirate systems Took me 6 hours walking to find my first ship, a fighter, but then they started to come together quicker. Got up to 7 glyphs in the starter system and the first pirate system, so made a freighter, then found a portal to get close to the center.

items.title: Monsters, Aliens, and Holes in the Ground
items.content_html:
Finished reading: Monsters, Aliens, and Holes in the Ground by Stu Horvath 📚

This was a great review of rpgs I’ve played or owned, and filled in on others, even ones I’ve not heard of. Ones I hadn’t thought of in ages, like the original TMNT and James Bond 007 books I had. Was interesting to learn about Vampire The Masquerade and other games I’d only associated with LARPing. He handled problematic games and/or authors in the beginning with a mention of some (like Empire of the Petal Throne) by acknowledging they exist but that they’re not in his collection or book because of the author’s… other work. I had been curious of EPT for a long time (they’re in some iteration of Appendix N, I think) but never read them due to their rarity, and was glad I hadn’t spent too much time or money tracking them down.
items.content_text:
Finished reading: [Monsters, Aliens, and Holes in the Ground](https://micro.blog/books/9780262048224) by Stu Horvath 📚

This was a great review of rpgs I've played or owned, and filled in on others, even ones I've not heard of. Ones I hadn't thought of in ages, like the original *TMNT* and *James Bond 007* books I had. Was interesting to learn about *Vampire The Masquerade* and other games I'd only associated with LARPing. He handled problematic games and/or authors in the beginning with a mention of some (like Empire of the Petal Throne) by acknowledging they exist but that they're not in his collection or book because of the author's... other work. I had been curious of EPT for a long time (they're in some iteration of Appendix N, I think) but never read them due to their rarity, and was glad I hadn't spent too much time or money tracking them down.

items.title: Gnucash Finance::Quote update
items.content_html:
Recent MacOS update broke the Perl/Finance::Quote/Gnucash axis, so GC couldn’t download quotes. Took a while to figure out that the chip architecture also fits into the issue, since Perl was updating F::Q to use an Apple Silicon version instead of the x86 version that Gnucash (currently running in Rosetta mode). Found fix here. Also required cleaning out Perl.

Just in case this happens again
items.content_text:
Recent MacOS update broke the Perl/Finance::Quote/Gnucash axis, so GC couldn't download quotes. Took a while to figure out that the chip architecture also fits into the issue, since Perl was updating F::Q to use an Apple Silicon version instead of the x86 version that Gnucash (currently running in Rosetta mode). Found fix [here](https://wiki.gnucash.org/wiki/Online_Quotes#Installing_Finance::Quote_on_macOS). Also required cleaning out Perl. 

Just in case this happens again

items.content_html:
LOTRO goals for February:

  • Finish up maxing crafting reputation tiers on minstrel & Lore-Master

  • Push minstrel to 150, maybe by going back and running through the epic that leads up to Umbar

  • Get brawler to 145, to open up the King’s Gondor & Umbar tasks

  • Gear up LM for the new instances

Not really in a huge hurry for any of this since we don’t know when the new instances will actually drop

LOTRO goals for February:

* Finish up maxing crafting reputation tiers on minstrel & Lore-Master

* Push minstrel to 150, maybe by going back and running through the epic that leads up to Umbar

* Get brawler to 145, to open up the King's Gondor & Umbar tasks

Not really in a huge hurry for any of this since we don't know when the new instances will actually drop

items.content_html: Starting to convert one of the WideLoaders on the xtracycle to have a spot to hold a bicycle wheel in place, if/when we need to bail out on the way home from summer camp. During the process, snapped the plastic connector on the LongLoader. Put a replacement together in tinkercad, primitive but it works so far:[Printables] (https://www.printables.com/model/488721-xtracycle-longloader-connector)

items.title: Secondhand
items.content_html:
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text: by Adam Minter. Got this from the library. Interesting research into the ultimate fates of things that are donated for resale and reuse. The amount of things tossed is horrible.

items.title: Weird Things Customers Say in Bookstores, Jen Campbell
items.content_html: This had one of the Staff Picks cards at the library. I sat down and read the whole thing in one sitting. Hilarious.
items.content_text: This had one of the Staff Picks cards at the library. I sat down and read the whole thing in one sitting. Hilarious.

items.title: Vaults of Obsidian
items.content_html: A Blackstone Fortress Anthology. A variety of stories about some of the characters in the game. I would love to read more about UR-025 at different times in his long history. The negavolt story is kind of horrifying.
items.content_text: A Blackstone Fortress Anthology. A variety of stories about some of the characters in the game. I would love to read more about UR-025 at different times in his long history. The negavolt story is kind of horrifying.

items.title: Dark Imperium: Plague Wars
items.content_html: Finished this last night. It’s been a while since I read the first one, so it took a bit to find my way. I kind of liked how the narrative jumped between the various main characters.
items.content_text: Finished this last night. It's been a while since I read the first one, so it took a bit to find my way. I kind of liked how the narrative jumped between the various main characters.

items.title: Shed Manual, John Coupe and Alex Johnson
items.content_html: Some good construction ideas and such. Thinking about a modified version of the 8X6, maybe with those glass bricks for windows and a green roof…
items.content_text: Some good construction ideas and such. Thinking about a modified version of the 8X6, maybe with those glass bricks for windows and a green roof...

items.title: Planning, Designing and Making Railway Layouts in Small Spaces, Richard Bardsley
items.content_html: I vaguely remember reading through this and a few other similar books on the same press, the last time I fell down a railway modeling hole. It is a good read, maybe not the best introduction–I had a few terms I had to look up. Good to keep this one in mind if/when I get closer to building something.
items.content_text: I vaguely remember reading through this and a few other similar books on the same press, the last time I fell down a railway modeling hole. It is a good read, maybe not the best introduction--I had a few terms I had to look up. Good to keep this one in mind if/when I get closer to building something.

items.title: State of the Union, Nick Hornby
items.content_html: Super quick read, liked it. Want to see the version that the cover said is coming to tv. Need to pay attention to the dialogue, he doesn’t set it up like “he said, she said”, just lines of dialogue.
items.content_text: Super quick read, liked it. Want to see the version that the cover said is coming to tv. Need to pay attention to the dialogue, he doesn't set it up like "he said, she said", just lines of dialogue.

items.title: Every Tool’s a Hammer
items.content_html: Finally picked up the Adam Savage book a few weeks ago. Part biography, part anecdotes about favorite tools, working methods, and storage philosophies. Liked it a lot.
items.content_text: Finally picked up the Adam Savage book a few weeks ago. Part biography, part anecdotes about favorite tools, working methods, and storage philosophies. Liked it a lot.

items.title: The Tao of Bill Murray
items.content_html: I kept thinking that either I’ve read a similar book before, or maybe even this one–I remember a lot of the anecdotal random encounters with Bill Murray stories.
items.content_text: I kept thinking that either I've read a similar book before, or maybe even this one--I remember a lot of the anecdotal random encounters with Bill Murray stories.

items.title: So you’ve been publicly shamed, Jon Ronson
items.content_html:
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text: This one came in off a hold at the library. Read it all in a couple days. I remember most of these awkward situations. Glad to not be on Twitter and minimally on Facebook.

items.title: Sharing a HP 1012 connected to a Mac with a Windows10 computer
items.content_html:
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text:
A couple things to remember:

  1. Install Bonjour Print Services.
  2. There isn't a driver for the 1012, so you have to use the HP Laserjet 3055 PS driver. The three 3055 PCL drivers didn't work. It is included in Windows10, shouldn't require an additional download.

items.title: Remote entry
items.content_html:
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text: Finally got the parts I needed for the 240 remote entry project: an salvaged lock solenoid and a kit of remotes plus the control brain, all off eBay. After a bit of fiddling to get the door card off, I got the solenoid mounted, the lock arm drilled and connected to the solenoid, and a wiring loom built. That wiring was run into the dash, across to the relays. I added a second harness for power and ground for the brain, which I put behind the glove box. I soldered all the wires together, and… nothing. The fuse that I thought would be hot all the time wasn't, but the system worked fine after I swapped the wire to fuse #8, the one that also powers stuff like the interior lights and the radio. Confusing, since the lists of functions look very similar for fuse #1 and #8.

items.title: Side marker lights
items.content_html: Sunday while I had the extended boil for the grätzer going I started on the next project for the Volvo: adding side marker lights. I recently picked up a set off eBay. The badges popped off easily enough, but the adhesive was another matter. I had to get back to the boil before I was 100% satisfied with it, but will revisit it when I finish this. The holes are right where they should be, which was great. No wiring harness, but that’s not too surprising.
items.content_text: Sunday while I had the extended boil for the grätzer going I started on the next project for the Volvo: adding side marker lights. I recently picked up a set off eBay. items.title: Workbench top lamination
items.content_html: Glued up the two butcher block tops for the workbench.
items.content_text: Glued up the two butcher block tops for the workbench.

items.title: Carving Tool Tray
items.content_html: Inspired by Peter Follansbee’s tray for chisels that I pinned about a year ago, I finally made one from some red oak scraps and leftover pieces from building the trays for the tool chest.
items.content_text: Inspired by Peter Follansbee's tray for chisels that I pinned about a year ago, I finally made one from some red oak scraps and leftover pieces from building the trays for the tool chest.

items.title: Pinot Noir 2013
items.content_html: Racked the 2013 Pinot Noir off of the oak today, looks good and clear.
items.content_text: Racked the 2013 Pinot Noir off of the oak today, looks good and clear.

items.title: Painting the completed tool chest
items.content_html: The tool chest took a while to paint due to low temperatures in the shop, and me not wanting to keep the heat on without being out there. Plus, I wanted to do a complex series of coats:
items.content_text:
The tool chest took a while to paint due to low temperatures in the shop, and me not wanting to keep the heat on without being out there. Plus, I wanted to do a complex series of coats:
  1. Three coats of slate milk paint, using the whole package up
  2. Two coats of boiled linseed oil
  3. Three coats of Federal Blue milk paint
  4. Two coats of gel polyurethane

items.title: Starting the tills
items.content_html: I have the top till walls all glued up, and have started fitting the floor.
items.content_text: I have the top till walls all glued up, and have started fitting the floor.

items.title: Runners
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->

items.title: Brief update to the bench
items.content_html:
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
<!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text: About my workbench: up until yesterday, I thought the door that makes up the top was completely solid core. It is not, at least in certain areas because I finally did something beyond the quick-release face vise...I finally drilled a couple holes for the Veritas hold down that I bought a long time ago to use with the saw bench. I added a 2x4 laid on its side, attached through the top with a few Miller dowels, in effect deepening the hole that the holddown goes through. It seems to work all right, at least well enough for me to finish the tool chest project and begin on the Roubo bench, which should be my next "big" project.

items.title: Lid of the toolchest
items.content_html:
So, the background on the lid: I had barely started it during the class. I chopped all four of the mortises, but that was about it, just one tenon cut and fitted. So in the last few days I worked on the other three corners:

Everything goes in with some pressure, no persuasion necessary. One corner is kinda loose, but I might pack some sawdust into that mortise to take up some of the slack. After creating a huge pile of curly shaving plowing the grooves, it is time for the glue!
items.content_text: So, the background on the lid: I had barely started it during the class. I chopped all four of the mortises, but that was about it, just one tenon cut and fitted. So in the last few days I worked on the other three corners: Everything goes in with some pressure, no persuasion necessary. One corner is kinda loose, but I might pack some sawdust into that mortise to take up some of the slack. After creating a huge pile of curly shaving plowing the grooves, it is time for the glue!

items.title: Albatross bars for the SimpleOne
items.content_html:
I used my birthday coupon code at Rivendell to get the bars and some accoutrement for switching from the Moustache bars that I bought it with to Albatross bars. I’ve come to really like sitting a bit more upright, with the Albas on the xtracycle and the Boscos on the Ram. I like the Moustache bars just fine, though… One last photo before I started to take them off:

For future reference, the folks at Riv taped them from the center to the brake hood with one piece, then a couple small bits to fit around the hoods, then from the hood to the end with another long piece.
items.content_text: I used my birthday coupon code at Rivendell to get the bars and some accoutrement for switching from the Moustache bars that I bought it with to Albatross bars. One last photo before I started to take them off: For future reference, the folks at Riv taped them from the center to the brake hood with one piece, then a couple small bits to fit around the hoods, then from the hood to the end with another long piece.

items.title: Casters
items.content_html:
Tonight I installed the casters that I picked up at Home Depot yesterday. It’s unfortunate that finding casters that have a) steel/metal wheels, and b) are made in the USA, is so difficult. I know they exist, from some deep googling, but the manufacturer’s websites request that you submit info for a quote, which makes me think they don’t sell directly to consumers in quantities of 4.

To attach the casters, I used 1" lag screws through the batten and a bit into the floor of the chest. Everything sounded ok as I cranked them down, and nothing went through the floor into the chest. Slowly flipped the chest over onto the casters… That should be the last time it’s upside down.
items.content_text: Tonight I installed the casters that I picked up at Home Depot yesterday. It's unfortunate that finding casters that have a) steel/metal wheels, and b) are made in the USA, is so difficult. I know they exist, from some deep googling, but the manufacturer's websites request that you submit info for a quote, which makes me think they don't sell directly to consumers in quantities of 4. To attach the casters, I used 1" lag screws through the batten and a bit into the floor of the chest. Everything sounded ok as I cranked them down, and nothing went through the floor into the chest. Slowly flipped the chest over onto the casters... That should be the last time it's upside down.

items.title: Saw Till
items.content_html:
I worked more on the saw till and sectional wall today. I plowed the kerfs for the saws to rest in. I think it might be easier to plow the ones on this inside first, then the two on the outside–I ended up using little wedges to keep the inner kerfs open while I made the outer ones. While cutting the semi-circle on the top, I ran into the same problem I had while cutting all the dovetails for the carcase, that poplar kind smushes and doesn’t cut a super crisp line.

Since Chris or Rob did all the tongue and groove cuts for the floors, I wanted to try doing that myself for the sectional wall. Getting the wide blade assembly and tongue blade all dialed in on my Veritas plow plane took me a while this first time, but once it was set up it worked fine. Jackie walked in while I was pushing the entire workbench around, and I think she understood my talk about a heavier workbench in the future.

Edit, 2013-09-20: I finished the cleats for the saw till and mounted them to the carcase with clinch rose head nails, and started work on the cleats for the rear corral area of the floor.

Since Chris or Rob did all the tongue and groove cuts for the floors, I wanted to try doing that myself for the sectional wall. Getting the wide blade assembly and tongue blade all dialed in on my Veritas plow plane took me a while this first time, but once it was set up it worked fine. items.title: Top skirt
items.content_html: Unfortunately no pictures of this. I decided during the class that since we’d done the glue-up of the lower skirt, that the upper skirt wouldn’t be much different, and that I could do it myself once I got home (that is, drop it and try and keep up with what the rest of the class was working on). That was true, but having a couple extra sets of hands was the key to it going so smooth there vs. here. My ability to get everything lined up and clamped was made worse by the high temperature in my shop. It is close, but not perfect.
